Realize. Reimagine. Reunite. was the theme of MPUSD’s annual Back to School Kick Off. Yesterday we welcomed all staff back with a powerful session incorporating student voice.

https://youtu.be/OryGu6xMBTs

Assistant Superintendent Dr. Manny Nunez challenged all staff to adopt six actions as we prepare for the start of school:

1. Listen with the intent to understand and not to respond.
2. Practice self awareness and become a better human being to other human beings.
3. Build your capacity to better understand the pain that our African-American community has and is still experiencing.
4. Build individual and collective consciousness for racial equity, identify your privilege and check your biases.
5. Grow in ways that lead to safe, respectful and supportive dialogues.
6. Lead with empathy, be intentional, and take action to create positive change.

This decision was difficult to make as we know that the best place for students is at school. One of our educators (Ms. Flanders) at Los Arboles Middle School shared this with her students today. She expressed that she found it online and gives credit to the original unknown poster, but we wanted all of our parents and guardians to see it.

“Dear Parents. Don’t stress about schoolwork. In September, I will get your children back on track. I am a teacher and that’s my superpower. What I can’t fix is social-emotional trauma that prevents the brain from learning. So right now, I just need you to share your calm, share your strength, and share your laughter with your children. No kids are ahead. No kids are behind. Your children are exactly where they need to be. With love, All the teachers on planet Earth.”
text:
One of our educators (Ms. Flanders) at Los Arboles Middle School shared this with her students today. She expressed that she found it online and gives credit to the original unknown poster, but we wanted all of our parents and guardians to see it.

“Dear Parents. Don’t stress about schoolwork. In September, I will get your children back on track. I am a teacher and that’s my superpower. What I can’t fix is social-emotional trauma that prevents the brain from learning. So right now, I just need you to share your calm, share your strength, and share your laughter with your children. No kids are ahead. No kids are behind. Your children are exactly where they need to be. With love, All the teachers on planet Earth.”

MPUSD’s Chief Business Officer Ryan Altemeyer highlighted MPUSD efforts as we pivoted to Distance Learning Adventures in CASBO’s Ed Funding podcast. If you have 32 minutes, it’s a great highlight on MPUSD’s shift.

Ryan shares how the district engaged all of its departments to determine what resources they already possessed, and surveyed families to identify needs. He also describes some "nuts and bolts" that went into preparing and distributing devices to those who needed them. MPUSD was able to build on technology and learning approaches already set up at their middle and high schools, so expanding access to elementary students became their focal point. It's all very much still a work in progress. Ryan also explains the “asynchronous” model his district is utilizing that enables students to work at their own pace with educators providing direction, support and guidance.

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE:

MPUSD Community,

Thank you for your patience and understanding as we continue to address the impacts related to the Coronavirus. We are doing our best to consolidate and communicate efficiently, but as new information becomes available we want to keep you in the loop.

Following up this afternoon’s message, we have new information regarding middle and high school athletics.

After much discussion and surveying our neighboring districts, the Monterey Peninsula Unified School District is cancelling ALL middle and high school athletic practices and games effective immediately through Friday, April 10th.

We will continue to monitor the state of the community and the status of the Coronavirus and follow guidance from our local and state health authorities.

We understand this news is disappointing, but felt this decision was necessary in order to protect the well-being of students and staff.

Again, thank you for your patience during this time.

The Monterey Peninsula Unified School District is looking for a progressive, talented, and passionate leader to serve as Assistant Principal in our Alternative Education Program which includes our Continuation School, Independent Study Program, and Community Day School.

Our ideal candidate is someone who is focused on equitable educational opportunities and desires to work with underserved students and seeks to be involved in shifting the life trajectories of our students. Our population includes students who are systems involved or have exhibited concerning behavior and need someone with the experience, love, and knowledge required to support them and the adults who work with them. The need for experience and understanding around MTSS and researched based interventions is essential. Being bilingual is not required but is a desired qualification.

More information can be found on the posting.

https://www.edjoin.org/Home/DistrictJobPosting/1225225
